Fig. 1 FT-IR spectra of (a) 1 and (b) 1′. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Powder XRD patterns of (a) Zr-UiO-66, (b) 1 and (c) 1′. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Pawley fitting results for 1. The theoretical and experimental patterns are represented, respectively by blue lines and red dots. Below these patterns, the difference plot and the peak markers are shown (Rwp = 2.63%, Rp = 1.62%). Fig 3 Fig. 4 FE-SEM images of 1′ (a) before and (b) after catalysis. Fig 4 Fig. 5 TGA curves of 1 and 1′ recorded under argon atmosphere between 25 and 700 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C min-1. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Time-yield profile for the Friedel-Crafts alkylation of IND with NS (a) using 1′ and (b) hot filtration experiment after removal of 1′ after 60 min. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Time-yield profile for the Friedel-Crafts alkylation of IND with NS using (a) ZrOCl2·8H2O, (b) UiO-66(Zr), (c) UiO-66(Ce), (d) ligand and (e) 1′. Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction efficiently catalyzed by a di-amide functionalized Zr(IV) metal-organic framework Subhrajyoti Ghosh Investigation Visualization Writing – original draft a Nagarathinam Nagarjun Investigation Visualization Writing – original draft b Masud Alam Investigation Visualization Writing – original draft a Amarajothi Dhakshinamoorthy Supervision Funding acquisition b ⁎ Shyam Biswas Supervision Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, Assam 781039, India Department of Chemistry Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati Assam 781039 India aDepartment of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, Assam 781039, India b School of Chemistry, Madurai Kamaraj University, Madurai, Tamil Nadu 625021, India School of Chemistry Madurai Kamaraj University Madurai Tamil Nadu 625021 India bSchool of Chemistry, Madurai Kamaraj University, Madurai, Tamil Nadu 625021, India ⁎ Corresponding authors. In this work, a di-amide functionalized Zr(IV) metal-organic framework (MOF, 1) was synthesized and characterized with powder XRD, FT-IR, FE-SEM and elemental analysis. Furthermore, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 showed thermal stability up to 275 °C. High chemical stability of the MOF was noticed in different organic solvents, under acidic and basic conditions. The BET surface area of this porous framework was 632 m2/g and pore volume was 0.35 cm3/g at p/po = 0.5. Activated MOF material (1′) displayed noticeable catalytic performance in the Friedel-Crafts alkylation between indole (IND) and β-nitrostyrene (NS). The desired product was obtained in quantitative yield using 1′ as a solid catalyst in ethanol at 40 °C. Catalyst stability was proved by leaching and reusability tests. This catalyst also exhibited broad substrate scope for the synthesis of various heterocyclic compounds. Comparison of the present catalytic results with reported data clearly indicates that this solid is able to promote the reaction effectively to attain higher yields by appropriate design of linker with amide functionality. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal-organic framework Zirconium Amide functionalization Friedel-Crafts alkylation 1 Introduction MOFs are porous crystalline materials [1,2] achieved by the assembly of metal ions/clusters with the rigid organic linkers through covalent linkage with high surface area [3–5]. Besides high surface area and porosity, one of the characteristic properties of MOFs is the precise installation of the active sites like Brönsted acids/bases, Lewis acids/bases and metal nanoparticles within the cavities of MOFs [6–10]. In the last decade, MOFs with these active sites were deeply exploited as solid catalysts to perform broad ranges of organic transformations with superior activity compared to analogous catalysts [11–16]. One of the challenging tasks in MOF catalysis is the design of new heterogeneous MOF-based catalysts with different active sites in their frameworks. This is often realized by appropriate selection of the organic linkers possessing the desired functional groups that can be facilely active upon coordinating with the suitable metal ions [17–21]. In this way, synthesis of new MOFs with different active sites would be desirable to achieve superior catalytic performance in organic transformations. Besides the use of MOFs in catalysis, MOFs have displayed potential capability to recognize different analytes through different mechanisms and found extensive applications in sensors [22,23]. Together with chemical recognition and separation of gas mixtures, these crystalline, porous, solid materials can also be applied for drug delivery [24], lithium-ion batteries [25], gas/vapor storage & separation [26] and photo-electrocatalysis [27]. Tunable surface area and porosity, high physicochemical stability, easy scope of functionalization even after synthesis make MOFs as interesting solids for the sensing of different analytes and various catalytic activities [28,29]. MOFs have been reported as heterogeneous catalysts for broad range of organic transformations utilizing any of the above commented active sites or combination of any two types of active sites, especially for cascade reactions [30]. One of the areas in which MOFs have attracted researchers is organic chemistry, particularly for the synthesis of heterocyclic compounds [31]. MOFs have been used as heterogeneous solids for the synthesis of broad range of heterocycles with wide substrate scope and above all, they can be reused. Some of the heterogeneous catalysts that have been reported for the synthesis of heterocycles are ZIF-like solid grafted with H6P2W18O62 as catalyst for the esterification of free fatty acids [32], H3PW12O40@Fe3O4/EN-MIL-101 (EN: ethylene diamine) for the synthesis of 2H-indazolo [2, 1-b] phthalazine-triones [33], EN grafted UiO‐66 for the synthesis of 2‐aminithiophenes [34], NbZr/KIT-6 as catalyst for the synthesis of benzylpyrazolyl coumarins [35] and H5PW10V2O40@VOx/SBA-15-NH2 for the synthesis of 3-substituted indoles [36]. Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction between IND and NS is considered as one of the straightforward approaches for the preparation of heterocyclic compounds bearing IND moiety exhibiting potential biological activity [37]. Further, the reaction of β-nitroalkene with N-alkylated indole like IND or 1-methylindole is slow due to poor nucleophilic nature of IND [38]. Using this reaction, series of heterocyclic compounds have been reported like tryptamine derivatives with non-N substituted indoles of biologically relevant neurotransmitter like serotonin [39], alkaloid like tryptophan [40] and anti-tumor drug such as lavendamycin [41]. On the other hand, several MOF catalysts having different active sites were reported for Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction of IND with NS. These catalysts include squaramide-functionalized UiO-67 MOF, Cu-UBTA, Cu(dbda), Cu3(BTC)2, UiO-66(Ce), Cr-MIL-101-UR3, urea functionalized [Zn4O(L3)(DMF)2]·3DMF, NU-601, UiO-67-urea and homochiral (R)-Cu-MOF-1. In the present manuscript, the activity of 1′ is reported in the Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction between IND and NS. The observed results clearly indicate that 1′ possesses different active sites compared to other reports in the literature, thus showing its multifunctional behavior. In addition, it is demonstrated clearly that the facile introduction of amide functionality in the UiO-66 motif triggers the catalytic activity significantly compared to parent UiO-66 solid. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of [Zr6O4(OH)4(BDC-(NHCOCH3)2)6)]·5H2O·3DMF (Zr-UiO-66-(NHCOCH3)2), (1) The BDC-(NHCOCH3)2 (2,5-bis-acetylamino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) ligand (26 mg, 0.09 mmol) (Figs. S1–S3), trifluoroacetic acid (214 µL, 30 mmol) and ZrOCl2·8H2O (30 mg, 0.09 mmol) were taken in a sealed tube containing 3 mL of DMF. Then, the mixture was sonicated for 10 min for the complete dissolution of metal salt and ligand. After that, the tube was kept at 120 °C for 24 h in a dry block heater. Yellowish color product was collected after washing several times with acetone through the filtration process. Then, the material was kept in an oven for 7 h at 70 °C. Yield: 33 mg (0.06 mmol, 66%). Anal. calcd. for C81H113N15O52Zr6 (2649 g mol-1): C, 36.44; H, 4.23; N, 7.87. Found C, 35.85; H, 4.03; N, 7.56%. IR (cm-1): 3434 (br), 3340 (br), 2932 (w), 2881 (w), 1667 (vs), 1587 (s),1530 (vs), 1426 (vs), 1366 (s), 1289 (s), 1200 (s), 1153 (m), 1025 (w), 963 (w), 917 (w), 793 (m), 723 (w), 651 (m), 538 (w), 487 (w). 2.2 Activation of compound 1 After synthesis, 20 mg of solid 1 was dispersed in 50 mL of CH3OH for overnight to remove weakly bound solvent/water molecules adsorbed on the pores. Later, CH3OH exchanged 1 solid was filtered and heated under the vacuum at 100 °C for 12 h. The recovered solid after heat treatment was named as 1′. 2.3 Experimental procedure for catalytic study For the Friedel-Craft alkylation reaction, a pressure tube (15 mL) was loaded with 10 mg of 1′, 0.1 mmol of IND, 0.1 mmol of NS and 0.2 mL of solvent. Then, this slurry was homogeneously mixed and placed in an oil bath maintained at 40 °C for 24 h. The evolution of the reaction was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) system by sampling aliquots at different time intervals. The purity, selectivity and yield of the products were also checked by GC using internal standard. The obtained products were characterized by GC–MS and 1H-NMR analyzes (Figs. S11–S22). Reusability test was conducted by following similar experimental conditions. The catalyst was recovered by filtration at the end of the catalytic reaction and washed with acetonitrile (3 mL) for three times. Later, it was dried at 100 °C for 3 h. This solid was used in the successive cycles with the fresh reactants in each cycle. 1H-NMR spectra were recorded using a Bruker AM 400 spectrometer. 1H-NMR spectra were recorded for the linker, NS and for the physical mixture containing linker (6 mg) with NS (3 mg) in NMR tube at different time intervals in DMSO-d6 solvent. 3 Results and discussion After the successful synthesis of the solid 1 and its activated form namely, 1′, these solids were characterized to confirm the formation of MOF structure and the presence of the functional groups. 3.1 Infrared spectroscopy To prove the existence of the functional groups and the successful elimination of solvents from 1, we performed FT-IR analysis for 1 and 1′ (Fig. 1 ). FT-IR spectra of 1 and 1′ showed two strong absorption bands around 1535 and 1426 cm-1 and are originated from the asymmetrical and symmetrical stretching of metal bound –CO2 groups of linker, respectively. There was another band at 1667 cm-1, which appeared from the –CO stretching of the amide functional group. In the as-synthesized material, we can observe a peak at 1587 cm-1 for –C=O vibration of DMF molecules. This absorption band was absent in the activated material (1′), which confirmed that 1′ is free of DMF molecules. 3.3 Structural overview This di-amide anchored, newly synthesized MOF (1) displayed very much similarity in PXRD pattern with the simulated diffractogram of literature reported un-functionalized UiO-66 type of MOF material (Fig. 2 ). The structural similarity between the un-functionalized UiO-66 and as-prepared 1 was further confirmed by the powder data indexing (Table S2) and Pawley fitting (Fig. 3 ). Indexing and Pawley fitting were executed using the PXRD data of 1. Lattice parameters obtained from the indexing confirmed the cubic nature of the framework structure which is similar to the parent Zr(IV) based UiO-66 MOF (Table S2). Reliable fitting between the powder diffractograms of pristine Zr-based UiO-66 and 1 was confirmed by the satisfactory values of Rwp and Rp (Rwp = 2.63% and Rp = 1.62%). Positions of the peaks and their intensities in PXRD patterns were also closely similar to each other (Fig. 3). Therefore, it can be concluded that both the frameworks are isostructural. Similar to the parent un-functionalized UiO-66 framework, this newly synthesized MOF is also constructed by hexanuclear [Zr6O4(OH)4]12+units. These clusters are bridged by the linkers. Similar to typical UiO-66 framework, here also larger sized (octahedral) and smaller sized (tetrahedral) structural voids are present. In the framework, each Zr-atom has a square antiprismatic geometry with a coordination number of 8. These discussions confirm that the pristine UiO-66 type of framework structure remains un-altered after incorporation of di-amide functionalized BDC linker in place of un-functionalized BDC linker. The PXRD pattern was not changed after thermal activation. This proved the robust nature of the framework structure after thermal activation (Fig. 2). Homogeneous distribution of cubic shaped crystals in FE-SEM images proved the phase purity and robust nature of the MOF material (Fig. 4 ). To verify the thermal stability of this newly synthesized MOF, we have performed TGA measurements for both 1 and 1′ (Fig. 5 ). Both the compounds exhibited thermal stability up to 275 °C in argon environment (Fig. 5). TGA curve of 1 displays three weight losses. Initially, from 25 to 103 °C, the first weight loss of 3.4% was observed (calculated: 3.4%) for elimination of 5 H2O molecules per formula unit. The second weight loss of 8.2% took place in between the temperature range of 103–275 °C (calculated: 8.1%) because of the loss of three encapsulated DMF molecules. At last, the framework collapsed after 275 °C due to the removal of linker. For 1′, the first weight loss of 1.2% was observed from 105 to 120 °C. It occurred because of adsorbed H2O elimination. After the temperature 275 °C, decomposition of 1′ was observed. Therefore, these data infer that both 1 and 1′ has lower thermal stability as compared to the other reported MOFs of UiO-66 family [42–44]. To check the chemical stability of the material, we have stirred it in different solvents (i.e. methanol, acetone, DMF, DCM, CH3CN, toluene, H2O and THF) for 12 h, in various acid solutions (1M-HCl and acetic acid) for 6 h and in different pH of NaOH solutions (pH = 8 and 10) for 4 h. Then, PXRD patterns were collected and no changes were observed in their PXRD patterns (Figs. S4, S5). Hence, from these observations, it is concluded that the structure of the material remains stable in the above mentioned liquid media and its chemical stability is similar to other reported UiO-66 MOFs [44–46]. This high chemical stability satisfies the criteria of a good heterogeneous solid catalyst. 3.6 N2 sorption analysis The N2 sorption isotherms (Fig. S6) of material 1′ displayed type-I behavior with a BET surface area of 632 m2g-1 and a pore volume of 0.35 cm3g-1 at p/po = 0.5. These values are lower than the un-functionalized UiO-66 material (surface area = 1147 m2g-1) [47]. We assume that due to the incorporation of the bulky functional group of -NHCOCH3, the free diffusion of N2 was prohibited which may be the reason behind for the lower BET surface area as well as pore volume of the MOF material 1′ as compared to other reported UiO-66 MOF materials [44,48,49]. The pore size distribution curve exhibited that the average pore diameter of 1′ is 15 Å (Fig. S24). 3.7 Catalytic performance in Friedel-Crafts alkylation The catalytic behavior of 1′ was examined in Friedel-Crafts alkylation of IND with NS. The reaction conditions were optimized with these substrates by varying solvents and catalyst loadings. The catalytic data in Table 1 indicate that the yield of the product is influenced by temperature, solvent and catalyst loading. Among the various experimental conditions tested, the maximum yield was observed using 1′ for the reaction between IND and NS in ethanol at 40 °C. Furthermore, the activity of corresponding metal salt and ligand under similar loading was significantly lower, thus suggesting the superior nature of this solid catalyst in promoting this reaction. In Fig. 6 , the yield as a function of time is shown for the Friedel-Crafts alkylation of IND with NS using 1′ under the optimized conditions. Further, the stability of catalyst was shown by performing leaching experiment. After removing the catalyst from the reaction system, the supernatant liquid was allowed to react further. These results from the leaching test are shown in Fig. 6. The data clearly suggest the heterogeneous nature of the reaction. Time yield plots are provided in Fig. 7 for the alkylation of IND with NS using ZrOCl2·8H2O, UiO-66(Zr), UiO-66(Ce), ligand and 1′. The catalytic results suggest that the performance of the metal salt and the linker with similar loading to catalyst is significantly lower than the solid catalyst 1′. However, the activity of the linker with similar loading as in 1′ is two-fold higher than the metal salt. This enhanced activity of the linker is due to the presence of hydrogen bond donating sites. On the other hand, the activity of UiO-66(Zr) and UiO-66(Ce) was much lower than 1′. These results further confirm the effective participation of the hydrogen bond donating sites in 1′ as active sites in this transformation. Comparison of these observations undoubtedly suggests that the higher activity of 1′ is not exclusively from the metal nodes of the solid. Furthermore, the distinct activity difference between UiO-66(Zr) and 1′ is attributed due to the existence of amide groups in the linker of the later solid, which are involved in the catalytic reaction as hydrogen bond donating sites. Scheme 1 shows the possible mechanism for the Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction between IND and NS using 1′ as a solid heterogeneous catalyst. The linker (2,5-diacetamidoterephthalic acid) in 1′ interacts with NS through hydrogen bonding as shown in Scheme 1. This interaction was proved by measuring 1H-NMR spectra measured by mixing the linker with NS in DMSO-d6 at different time intervals. The amide protons in the linker appeared at 10.64 ppm while the addition of NS to the linker shifted the amide protons to downfield region of 10.70, 10.72 and 10.73 ppm after 1, 3 and 5 h, respectively (Fig. 8 ). These findings are in consistent with a previous precedent [50]. Furthermore, hydrogen bonding donating sites have been proposed as active sites for the promotion of this reaction [51–56]. This hypothesis was proved by observing higher catalytic performance with 1′ and 2,5-diacetamidoterephthalic acid linker than that of UiO-66(Zr), UiO-66(Ce) and metal salt under identical conditions. Furthermore, this interaction causes an electron deficiency in the C=C double bond of NS. Later, IND attacks NS through the C3 carbon atom to afford the excepted product. Besides leaching test, the stability of 1′ was also proved by performing reusability test and the observed results are given in Table 1. These data indicate that the activity of the reused 1′ is almost close to the activity of the fresh solid, thus, suggesting the high stability of 1′. Further, the stability of the reused solid was confirmed by characterizing with powder XRD, SEM and BET analysis. Fig. 9 shows the powder XRD of the fresh and reused solids. The intensity of peaks and their positions in the reused solid remained almost identical compared to the fresh solid. These observations suggest the retainment of structural integrity after reusability test. On the other hand, SEM image of the reused solid showed similar morphology to the fresh solid indicating that no structural damages occurred during catalysis (Fig. 4). In addition, BET surface area was measured for the reused solid and compared with the fresh solid. The BET surface area for the reused solid was 612 m2g-1 (Fig. S23) which is not much decreased compared to the fresh solid (632 m2g-1). These data confirmed that the structural integrity of the reused catalyst is similar to the fresh catalyst. Table S2 compares the activity of 1′ with other related works containing hydrogen bond donating sites as active sites. It was proved that the activity of MOFs with hydrogen bond donating sites is superior compared to pristine MOFs without hydrogen bond donating sites. This enhanced activity is ascribed to the uniform distribution of hydrogen bond donating sites in the porous network. Further, self-aggregation of hydrogen bond donating sites is avoided while they are assembled in the network. Similarly, the activity of 1′ is superior to other reported catalysts mentioned in Table S2 since the reaction is carried out at 40 °C. In addition, the present work illustrates the use of amide groups as hydrogen bond donating sites as compared to squaramide or urea based active sites. These encouraging results triggered us to examine the performance of 1′ with other substrates under identical conditions. In Table 2 , the achieved catalytic results are shown. The reaction of IND and NS in the presence of 1′ afforded the desired product in quantitative yield under the optimized conditions (entry 1, Table 2). Furthermore, 1-methyl, 2-methyl and 5-methoxyindoles efficiently reacted with NS to afford the desired products in 89, 97 and 90% yields, respectively (entries 2–4, Table 2). These results indicate that these substrates do not experience diffusion limitation to reach the active sites. In contrast, the reaction between 5-nitroindole and NS with 1′ showed no product formation (entry 5, Table 2). Interestingly, 5-bromoindole reacted with NS in the presence of 1′ to provide 51% yield (entry 6, Table 2). This lower yield compared to previous substrates is due to the bulky nature of bromine, thus encountering diffusion limitation to reach the active sites. On the other hand, this result can also be considered as an evidence for the occurrence of catalytic reaction within the pores of 1′. Interestingly, pyrrole reacted with NS to give the expected adduct in 93% yield (entry 7, Table 2). On the other hand, N,N-dimethylaniline reacted with NS using 1′ with 15% yield under identical conditions (entry 8, Table 2). This behavior is also due to the bulky size of the substrate as well as its reactivity compared to indoles. 4 Conclusions A robust Zr-UiO-66 MOF (1) with diamide functionality was successfully synthesized under solvothermal conditions and was extensively characterized with series of spectroscopic/microscopic techniques. Both as-synthesized and thermally activated solids showed thermal stability up to 275 °C. The stability of the material was also shown in various solvents, acidic and various pH solutions to satisfy the criteria for heterogeneous catalysis. The BET surface area of 632 m2g-1 with a pore volume of 0.35 cm3g-1 at p/po = 0.5 proved the porous nature of 1′. In addition, a quantitative yield of the product for the reaction of IND and NS with 1′ in the Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction under mild reaction conditions indicated superior activity of this solid compared to previous reports. This enhanced activity is ascribed to the facile introduction of amide functionalities in the linker which are behaving as hydrogen bond donating sites as observed in squaramide/urea systems. One of the advantages of this catalytic system is the facile preparation of this catalyst without employing costly ligands. Catalyst exhibited high stability as evidenced from the leaching and reusability tests. coredata.dc:description: In this work, a di-amide functionalized Zr(IV) metal-organic framework (MOF, 1) was synthesized and characterized with powder XRD, FT-IR, FE-SEM and elemental analysis. Furthermore, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 showed thermal stability up to 275 °C. High chemical stability of the MOF was noticed in different organic solvents, under acidic and basic conditions. The BET surface area of this porous framework was 632 m2/g and pore volume was 0.35 cm3/g at p/po = 0.5. Activated MOF material (1′) displayed noticeable catalytic performance in the Friedel-Crafts alkylation between indole (IND) and β-nitrostyrene (NS). The desired product was obtained in quantitative yield using 1′ as a solid catalyst in ethanol at 40 °C. Catalyst stability was proved by leaching and reusability tests. This catalyst also exhibited broad substrate scope for the synthesis of various heterocyclic compounds. Comparison of the present catalytic results with reported data clearly indicates that this solid is able to promote the reaction effectively to attain higher yields by appropriate design of linker with amide functionality.
coredata.dc:title: Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction efficiently catalyzed by a di-amide functionalized Zr(IV) metal-organic framework
